The main objective of the project is to develop new stochastic models for important financial systems such as equity, foreign exchange, bond, and credit markets through stochastic differential equations (SDEs) with discontinuous coefficients and with degeneracies. Discontinuous coefficients introduce a rich family of probabilistic models that capture abrupt transitions from one phase to another phase of random phenomena. The degeneracy of the diffusion coefficients brings to the system some interesting mixtures of stochastic dynamics and deterministic dynamics in the neighborhood around the domain of degeneracy. A prototypical tractable example is a system of SDEs with piece-wise constant drift/diffusion coefficients, which can be applied to financial mathematics in the context of stochastic portfolio theory. The investigator tackles new problems in SDEs with piece-wise constant coefficients, works towards more general models with degeneracy and discontinuous coefficients, and applies these mathematical results to improve understanding of the complicated global financial system. The problems include boundary behaviors, ergodicity, large deviations, weak/strong solvability of forward and backward SDEs with discontinuous coefficients and boundary conditions, large-scale optimal portfolio choice, and long-term stochastic optimizations.

The investigator studies financial systems by developing and analyzing new models of stochastic dynamics that may capture elastic changes and aberrant risky phenomena in the system. Those anomalies are caused by uncertainty inherent in the financial system. It is important to understand the properties of the models and to propose good safeguards, in order to increase efficiency of the financial system and to prevent its failure. Another feature of the proposed work is to capture, describe, and predict the evolution of the financial system. The greater understandings of the financial market mechanism that result from these studies can potentially increase efficiency of long-term financial investments. In addition, mathematical methods developed in the project may contribute to several areas of mathematics -- partial differential equations, combinatorics, geometry, and general dynamical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The start of this research project ``Financial markets with discontinuities" was to shed new lights on the study of excursion theory of stochastic processes in the context of financial systems such as equity, foreign exchange, bond and credit markets. In the past the probabilistic excursion theory has been developed for a class of stochastic systems called Markov processes, where the future random phenomena occur independently of the history of random events, given the current status. However, it was not suitable for the study of financial systems, because they exhibit non-Markov behaviors up to some extent. In this project the investigation extended the scope of stochastic processes described by stochastic differential equations with discontinuous coefficients and with degeneracy, in particular, the class of semimartingales for the study of boundary behaviors of such stochastic processes. Here the boundary behaviors mean mathematically that the trajectories of stochastic processes over time intersect with some neighborhood of topological sets, and in the financial context they include competitions, defaults and recovery of financial institutions in financial markets. Another contribution from the early stage of the project was to extend the excursion theory from one-dimensional to high dimensional stochastic processes in the study of complicated, global financial systems. This study allowed to define well some stochastic systems with degeneracy and discontinuous coefficients, at the weak point of other mathematical methods such as partial differential equations and functional analysis. Upon establishing this method, the principal investigator examined with the collaborators how the Markov property and other analytically good properties are restored under additional technical assumptions by the probabilistic methods, in particular, martingale characterization and stochastic analysis. 

The investigation continued with the study of ergodicity and weak/strong solution of forward and backward stochastic differential equations. The weak convergence results of such stochastic systems with discontinuous coefficients yield some understanding of continuity and stability in the system. This part of study is to describe the long-term evolution and helps to foresee the status of future financial system. Another direction of investigation conducted in the project was to extend the finite system of stochastic differential equations to the infinite system, where the number of participants or agents in the financial markets are considered to be infinite. This approach known as mean-field approximation made the analyses simpler significantly, because the interconnection among the financial agents can be averaged out. This part was closely related to the study of large particle systems and hydrodynamics in Physics and Chemistry, as each financial agent can be seen as a tiny particle because its overall presence and effects in the large system dissipate, as the number of particles grows to infinity. The investigaion determined mathematically under which circumstances the interactions among the agents in the financial markets can be ignored in the limits.   

The aim of this research project was successfully fulfilled by the generous supports from the foundation. During the course the project provided 14 undergraduate students (among them five were women and one represented minority), 1 master student from overseas and 2 PhD students research training opportunities in the study of financial markets with discontinuities. The results obtained in the project were presented and discussed in the research conferences and workshops (14 international and 19 domestic meetings), and then submitted to refereed research journals for publication. The mathematical results and outcomes from this project will potentially make some impacts in the study of Finance, Economics and Insurance, because of the subject matter, as well as in Physics and Chemistry.
